item.title: Sri Lanka Was Warned of Possible Attacks. Why Didn’t It Stop Them?
item.media:description: An advisory sent by a Sri Lankan police official this month warned of a threat from National Thowheeth Jama’ath, a radical Islamist group that government officials have blamed for the attacks.
item.description: The government’s history of bitter infighting appears to have contributed to a spectacular security blunder that led to one of the world’s deadliest terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN, MUJIB MASHAL and DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: Live Briefing: Sri Lanka Bombings Live Updates: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Attacks
item.media:description: Mourners at the mass funeral at St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka, on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The government said the bombers got help overseas for the bombings, which killed more than 300 people, and some of them had been in Syria, a base for the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: What We Know and Don’t Know About the Sri Lanka Attacks
item.media:description: Friends and relatives console a boy at the burial on Monday of three family members killed in the Sri Lanka attacks.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: More information is emerging about who planned the attacks and who was killed, but essential questions remain unanswered.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Victims of Sri Lanka Attacks: Who They Were
item.media:description: Friends and relatives at the burial of three members of one family who died in the bomb blast at St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The identities of the victims in the Sri Lanka bombings have started to emerge.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: New I.R.A. Apologizes for Killing of Journalist in Northern Ireland
item.media:description: Flowers left in tribute to a 29-year-old journalist, Lyra McKee, near where she was shot last week in Londonderry, Northern Ireland.
item.description: Under heavy criticism, the republican paramilitary group took the unusual step of admitting its role in Lyra McKee’s death.
item.dc:creator: ED O’LOUGHLIN

item.title: The Son Protested the Dictator. The Father Helped Throw Him Out.
item.media:description: Protesters in Khartoum last week listened as activists from Darfur gave speeches against the regime of Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the former president.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Lt. Gen. Salah Abdelkhalig is now among the most powerful men in Sudan, having ousted former president Omar Hassan al-Bashir at the urging of protesters like the general’s son.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Why Has Australia Fallen Out of Love With Immigration?
item.media:description: Central Station in Sydney, where a growing population has helped lead to more crowded commutes.
item.media:credit: Anna Maria Antoinette D’Addario for The New York Times
item.description: With its largest cities struggling to manage growth and after years of anti-immigrant rhetoric from politicians, most Australians now say their country no longer needs more people.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE and ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: Myanmar’s Highest Court Upholds Conviction of Reuters Journalists
item.media:description: The Reuters journalists U Kyaw Soe Oo, front, and U Wa Lone after a court hearing in Yangon, Myanmar, last year. They have been in prison for 16 months.
item.description: The reporters, U Wa Lone and U Kyaw Soe Oo, won a Pulitzer Prize earlier this month for their reporting on a military massacre of Rohingya Muslims.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and SAW NANG
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Philippines Struck by Another Powerful Earthquake
item.media:description: Cracks in a road caused by a 6.4-magnitude earthquake that was centered in Samar, an island in the central eastern part of the Philippines, on Tuesday.
item.description: The latest earthquake was centered in Samar, an island in the central eastern part of the country. It came after a quake near Manila killed at least 15 people.
item.dc:creator: JASON GUTIERREZ and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Photos From Sri Lanka: Grappling With Tragedy
item.media:description: A mass funeral on Tuesday at St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka. As many as 100 people were killed in a suicide bombing at the church on Easter Sunday.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Images from the devastation of the Easter Sunday bombings show glimpses of how the country is starting to mourn.

item.title: Scenes From Mass Burials for Victims of Sri Lanka Bombings
item.description: The first mass burials of the victims of the suicide attacks in Sri Lanka were on Tuesday. The death toll has risen to 321, and many of the coffins at the funerals held the remains of children.

item.title: Myanmar Jade Mine Disaster Feared to Have Killed More Than 50
item.media:description: At the scene of the mining disaster on Tuesday in Kachin State in northern Myanmar.
item.description: A huge mound of tailings collapsed into an open-pit mine in a remote area of Kachin State, burying workers and heavy equipment, officials said.
item.dc:creator: SAW NANG and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Trump’s State Visit to Britain, Long Delayed, Now Has a Date
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II greeted President Trump at Windsor Castle, England, in July.
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II formally invited the American leader to a three-day visit in June, when events for the 75th anniversary of D-Day will be held.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: New Zealand Offers Permanent Visas to Those at Mosques During Attacks
item.media:description: Evening prayers at the Linwood mosque in Christchurch, New Zealand, a day after its reopening last month.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The move followed public pleas from survivors and family members of the Christchurch victims for certainty about their immigration status.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY

item.title: Philippine Communist Rebels Kill 6 Soldiers, Military Says
item.description: The attack was claimed by the New People’s Army, the Communist guerrillas who have been waging an insurgency in the Philippines since 1969.
item.dc:creator: JASON GUTIERREZ

item.title: This Estonian Start-Up Has Become a Thorn in Uber’s Side
item.media:description: Based in Estonia, Bolt has become Uber’s most formidable challenger in Europe and Africa.
item.media:credit: Maxim Mjodov for The New York Times
item.description: The Estonian ride-hailing company Bolt is an unexpected success story. The start-up points to Uber’s global challenges.
item.dc:creator: ADAM SATARIANO

item.title: Sri Lanka, Iran, Trump: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: Relatives lighting candles on Monday after the burial of three family members who died at St. Sebastian's Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka, during a bombing on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: MELINA DELKIC

item.title: Letter 103: In Australia, Are All Historic Losses Treated Equally?
item.media:description: Susanne Craig addressing The New York Times newsroom after she, Russ Buettner, to her right, and David Barstow, to Mr. Buettner's right, won the Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting.
item.description: The burning of Notre-Dame cathedral has raised a question: Whose losses do we grieve?
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: What the Scale of the Sri Lankan Attacks Tells Us
item.description: The way the Easter Sunday events unfolded shows a level of sophistication and coordination that resulted in one of the deadliest terror attacks in modern history.

item.title: Sri Lanka, Impeachment, Earth Day: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA KANNAPELL and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: In Paraguay, Fighting Graft With Eggs and Toilet Paper
item.media:description: Loud, raucous — and often messy — protests against corruption have spread across Paraguay.
item.media:credit: Santi Carneri for The New York Times
item.description: Paraguayans fed up with corruption discovered that public shame was more effective than state institutions at holding crooked politicians accountable.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO and SANTI CARNERI

item.title: Sri Lanka, India, China: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: Mourners at St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday.

item.description: Security failures in Sri Lanka
item.dc:creator: ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: ‘These Attacks Could Target Catholic Churches’: The Warning That Sri Lankan Officials Failed to Heed
item.media:description: The cover page of the advisory.
item.description: This confidential security memo laid out specific names, addresses and phone numbers ten days before devastating attacks. But no action was taken.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Deadly Earthquake Hits the Philippines
item.description: An earthquake with a registered magnitude of 6.1 hit the northern Philippines, killing up to eight people, according to officials.

item.title: Sri Lankans Mourn Victims of Easter Sunday Bombings
item.media:description: Friends and relatives of Sneha Savindi Fernando, 11, in Negombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday. She was killed in a suicide bombing at St. Sebastian’s Church.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The day after coordinated attacks on churches and hotels across Sri Lanka, one Catholic neighborhood mourned its dead.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: Strong Earthquake Strikes Philippines, Killing 11 People
item.media:description: Outside a condominium building in Makati City, the Philippines, after an earthquake on Monday.
item.description: The quake, which had a magnitude of 6.1, caused several buildings to collapse and knocked out power near the capital, Manila.
item.dc:creator: JASON GUTIERREZ

item.title: U.S. Moves to Stop All Nations From Buying Iranian Oil, but China Is Defiant
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the United States would no longer grant oil waivers to China and India, Iran’s two largest customers.
item.description: Oil prices rose to their highest levels since October in anticipation of Monday’s announcement by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. Trump administration officials had debated the move.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Sri Lanka, Ukraine, ‘Game of Thrones’: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: A funeral today for one of the victims of the attack at St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka.

item.description: Here’s what you need to know.

item.title: Grief, and Questions, After the Attacks in Sri Lanka
item.media:description: The wake on Monday of Sneha Savindi, 11, who was killed in the suicide bombing at St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Images from the devastation of the Easter Sunday attacks and glimpses of how the country is starting to mourn.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Local Group Is Blamed for Attacks, but Sri Lanka Suspects ‘International Network’
item.media:description: St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday, a day after it was struck in a coordinated attack on churches and hotels.
item.description: Officials said the coordinated assaults had been carried out by National Thowheeth Jama’ath. They are investigating whether the attackers had help from overseas.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and SANDRA E. GARCIA

item.title: Live Briefing: Pointing a Finger at a Terrorist Group in the Aftermath of the Sri Lanka Blasts
item.media:description: Relatives unloading the coffin on Monday of Sneha Savindi, 11, who was killed in a suicide bombing at St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Officials could not explain why a warning about a militant Islamist organization planning suicide bombings failed to stop the assaults, which killed more than 300 people.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka, on Sunday after a bomb blast.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: MELINA DELKIC and ANDREA KANNAPELL

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Replaces Head of Revolutionary Guards
item.media:description: Brig. Gen. Hossein Salami was named the head of the Revolutionary Guard Corps in Iran and promoted to major general.
item.description: The replacement came two weeks after President Trump designated the Revolutionary Guards as a foreign terrorist organization.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Northern Ireland Police Release 2 Teenagers Arrested in Journalist’s Death
item.media:description: Police officers in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, on Saturday searching the ground ground near where Lyra McKee was shot and killed last week.
item.description: Two teenagers who were detained in the shooting death of a 29-year-old journalist in Northern Ireland were let go from police custody Sunday night without being charged.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Religious Minorities Across Asia Suffer Amid Surge in Sectarian Politics
item.media:description: The bombings of three churches in Sri Lanka on Easter Sunday highlighted the vulnerability of Christians in Asia.
item.description: The bombings of three churches in Sri Lanka highlighted the growing vulnerability of religious minorities across Asia, from Christians in Hindu-majority India to Muslims in Buddhist-majority Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH, DHARISHA BASTIANS and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: What We Know and Don’t Know About the Sri Lanka Bombings
item.media:description: Soldiers inspecting St. Sebastian’s Church, the site of the deadliest attack on Sunday, in Negombo, a city about 20 miles north of Colombo.
item.description: Coordinated attacks killed more than 290 people in churches, the largest targeted assault on South Asian Christians in recent memory.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sri Lanka, India, Dreamliner: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: The roof was blown off St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, north of Colombo.
item.description: Coordinated suicide bombings strike Sri Lanka
item.dc:creator: ANDREA KANNAPELL

item.title: Ukraine Election: Volodymyr Zelensky, TV Comedian, Trounces President
item.media:description: Volodymyr Zelensky, center right, at his campaign headquarters in Kiev on Sunday.
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky, an actor best known for playing a president on television, decisively won the race, with nearly all votes officially counted.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and IULIIA MENDEL

item.title: Ecuador Detains a Friend of Assange. Critics Say It’s Guilt by Association.
item.media:description: An anti-government protest in Quito that was prompted in part by Ecuador’s decision to no longer protect the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange.
item.description: Internet and free speech activists have come out in defense of Ola Bini, a Swedish cybersecurity expert, saying there is no evidence yet of a crime.
item.dc:creator: JOSÉ MARÍA LEÓN CABRERA

item.title: For Palestinian Families, ‘No Light at the End of the Tunnel’
item.media:description: Dina Teeti with her father, Hasan, who together run a wedding-planning company in the West Bank city of Nablus.
item.media:credit: Corinna Kern for The New York Times
item.description: The re-election of Benjamin Netanyahu, shortly after he vowed to apply Israeli sovereignty over the West Bank, was the latest blow to Palestinian aspirations for a state.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER and MIRIAM BERGER

item.title: The Interpreter: Sri Lanka Blocks Social Media, Fearing More Violence
item.media:description: Sri Lankan soldiers secured the area around St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo after a blast on Sunday.
item.description: Sri Lankan officials have a troubled relationship with social media. They have seen firsthand how quickly online hate can turn into deadly violence.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: For Sri Lanka, a Long History of Violence
item.media:description: The scene after a Tamil Tiger suicide bombing at a mosque in Godapitiya, Sri Lanka, in 2009.
item.description: The small island nation is famous for its beauty, but also for a brutal three-decade civil war and sectarian tensions that still simmer.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Sri Lanka Attacks: Nation On Edge Mourns Victims
item.description: The death toll from the Easter Sunday bombings in Sri Lanka was raised to nearly 300 people and the authorities have blamed a little-known radical Islamist group for the attacks.

item.title: Images of the Destruction and Despair in Sri Lanka
item.media:description: St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, north of Colombo, after a string of explosions across the country on Sunday.
item.description: Images of the churches that were attacked showed smashed pews, broken statues and charred beams. Windows, floors and ceilings were blown out at the hotels.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Police Warned That Sri Lanka Churches Were Bombing Targets
item.media:description: Covered bodies and debris in St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo, Sri Lanka, after a string of explosions ripped through hotels and churches on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Multiple explosions killed more than 200 people at churches and across the country. Thirteen people have been arrested.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: HELSINKI DISPATCH: Finland’s Hobbyhorse Girls, Once a Secret Society, Now Prance in Public
item.media:description: “The normal things, that normal girls like, they don’t feel like my things,” said Fanny Oikarinen, an 11-year-old hobbyhorse enthusiast.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: For years, a subculture of teenage hobbyhorse enthusiasts flourished under the radar. Now the craze is a national export, and a celebration of girlhood.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and DMITRY KOSTYUKOV

item.title: Blasts Targeting Christians Kill Hundreds in Sri Lanka
item.media:description: Sri Lankan military officials standing guard at St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo on Sunday. The clock, top left, is stuck at 8:45 a.m., the time of the attack.
item.description: The bombings shattered the relative calm of the once war-ravaged island nation amid a rise of religious extremism in South Asia.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS, JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and KAI SCHULTZ
